content.text: Intent reference: projects/IDSE_Core/sessions/supabase/intents/intent.md -> # Intent for Supabase Integration
Use this template to capture the environment, constraints, and risks that shape architecture, plans, and tasks.

- **Product / Project:** What product or project does this feature belong to? - **Domain:** Which business or technical domain does it operate in? - **Users / Actors:** Who will use or be affected by this feature (roles, personas)?
Describe only the portions of the stack that influence design decisions.

- **Frontend:** Frameworks, state management, styling. - **Backend / API:** Languages, frameworks, hosting. - **Database / Storage:** Primary databases, queues, caching. - **Infrastructure:** Cloud, orchestration, serverless. - **Integrations:** External APIs, services, systems to communicate with.
Explicit constraints that influence the solution (technical, organizational, regulatory, business).

- **Scale:** Expected users, data volumes, throughput. - **Performance:** Latency targets, throughput goals. - **Compliance / Security:** Residency (e.g., GDPR), encryption, auth protocols. - **Team Capabilities:** Skills and time availability. - **Deadlines:** Delivery timelines or releases. - **Legacy Considerations:** Systems/APIs that cannot change.
Identify risks and unknowns early to mitigate or research.

- **Technical Risks:** Unfamiliar tech, scalability, coupling. - **Operational Risks:** Deployment complexity, monitoring, backup/restore. - **Regulatory Risks:** Privacy concerns, certification needs. - **Unknowns:** Areas needing research, PoCs, or stakeholder clarification.
- Supabase as the backend service. - Considerations for authentication and query performance.
- Ensure authentication is tested thoroughly. - Review document storage migration process for issues.
Use this template to translate a specification into a concrete implementation plan. Each section should be tailored to the feature or project and stay aligned with the IDSE constitution.
Provide a high-level overview of the system/feature. Describe major components and how they interact. Link to diagrams (SVG, sequence, component) if helpful.
List services, modules, libraries, or functions. For each, note responsibility, boundaries, and interactions.
List entities and relationships. Include schemas (SQL/NoSQL), indexes, and normalization/denormalization choices. For event-driven designs, include event schemas.

- Endpoint / Method / Path - Description - Request: URL, headers, body (required/optional fields) - Response: status codes, headers, body (types) - Error handling: codes/messages - Security: authn/authz, rate limits
IDSE mandates test-first; describe validation before implementation:

- Unit: modules/functions with mocks. - Contract: API schemas and backward compatibility. - Integration: component/service/DB interactions. - End-to-end: user workflows. - Performance: scalability/latency under load. - Security: auth flows, input validation.
Include environments/tooling (e.g., Jest, PyTest, Postman, Cypress) and success criteria.
Break work into phases; each should deliver incremental value and be independent where possible.

- Phase 0: Foundations (architecture decisions, documented schemas, API contracts). - Phase 1: Core behavior (documented implementation approach). - Phase 2: NFRs (scale, security, resilience strategies). - Phase 3: Cleanup/Hardening (refinements, additional validation).

**Note:** This plan is **documentation** that guides the IDE/development team. The actual code, schemas, and configurations will be created by the development team in the appropriate codebase directories (src/, backend/, frontend/, etc.).

- Derive tasks directly from the implementation plan and contracts. - For each task, note owner, dependencies, and acceptance/validation notes. - Keep tasks independent and testable; mark parallelizable tasks with [P]. - **These tasks guide the IDE/development team** - they describe what needs to be done, not where code should be written.

To set up a new session for Supabase integration within the IDSE Core project.
1. Define Supabase schema. 2. Set up authentication and authorization. 3. Integrate Supabase with the application.
- Successful connection to Supabase. - Auth works as expected. - New data can be inserted and queried.
This session aims to integrate Supabase into the IDSE Core project, focusing on schema setup, authentication, and data handling.

Integrating Supabase as the backend solution aligns with our goal of simplifying authentication and document storage in our application. By leveraging Supabase’s capabilities, we aim to enhance user experience through seamless authentication, real-time data interactions, and robust document management. This integration will facilitate team collaboration and streamline our development process.

- **Technical Constraints**: Ensure compatibility with existing architecture and dependencies. - **Legal Compliance**: Adhere to data protection regulations such as GDPR when handling user data. - **Timeframe**: Target completion within the next sprint (4 weeks).

- **Risk**: Potential downtime during migration to Supabase. - **Mitigation**: Schedule migration during off-peak hours and implement fallback options. - **Risk**: User acceptance of the new authentication method. - **Mitigation**: Conduct training sessions and provide documentation prior to the rollout.
- Created initial specs and plans for Supabase integration.
This project includes the integration of Supabase for document storage and authentication.
- [ ] Check Supabase connectivity. - [ ] Validate schema configurations. - [ ] Ensure authentication works correctly.

Break work into phases; each should deliver incremental value and be independent where possible.

Testing is first-class in IDSE. Use this template to define the test plan before implementation. It ensures requirements are verifiable and each component has clear acceptance criteria.
- Goal of the feature and what this plan covers. - In-scope components and out-of-scope areas.

- Verify notifications reach the correct user within 2 seconds. - Ensure unauthenticated requests are rejected. - Confirm migrations create the correct schema. - Validate reconnection logic fetches missed notifications.
Describe the types of tests and tools/frameworks to be used.
- Focus on individual functions/classes; use mocks/stubs to isolate deps; target critical logic coverage.
- Define API schemas (OpenAPI, GraphQL). Test that responses match contract and cover error conditions.
- Verify components work together; connect to real or in-memory DBs, brokers, external services; cover end-to-end event flows.
- Simulate user behavior through UI/backend (e.g., Cypress, Playwright, Selenium). Validate acceptance criteria.
- Measure performance under load (e.g., k6, Locust); set baselines; find bottlenecks.
- Check authentication, authorization, input validation; include static/dynamic analysis where applicable.
- Describe environment versions (languages, frameworks, DBs). - Note differences from production and any required services.
- Define needed data: sample API payloads, DB fixtures, environment variables for secrets.

- Define measurable success, e.g.: - All tests pass in CI before merge. - Performance: median latency <2 seconds at target load. - No unhandled exceptions in logs during integration runs. - E2E acceptance scenarios all pass.
- How results are reported (CI dashboards, badges, JUnit reports). - How failures are triaged and communicated.
Use this plan before writing code to align developers, testers, and stakeholders on verification and quality standards.
To set up a new session for Supabase integration within the IDSE Core project.
1. Define Supabase schema. 2. Set up authentication and authorization. 3. Integrate Supabase with the application.
- Successful connection to Supabase. - Auth works as expected. - New data can be inserted and queried.
